0: A Spirit Airlines pilot and wife died of overdoses of cocaine and carfentanil, a drug so powerful its primary use is to tranquilize rhinos and elephants, the Montgomery County Coroner’s office confirmed Tuesday. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR >> NEW: ‘Speedball’ use by Centerville pilot not first at Spirit Airlines NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR >> EARLIER: Couple’s death may be fentanyl related NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR >> MORE: Spirit Airlines pilot’s overdose raises safety questions NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Brian Halye, 36, and Courtney Halye, 34, were found dead in their Centerville home March 16 by their four children who reported the deaths to police. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The toxicology results confirm what the coroner’s office had previously hinted at: the commercial passenger airline pilot died of an accidental drug overdose. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The deaths came a week after Brian Halye’s last flight, prompting criticism of the random system used to test pilots. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Local health officials say the results are consistent with an increasing pattern of people using extremely powerful drugs, and combining potent opioids like fentanyl and carfentanil with cocaine and other drugs. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Cocaine, opioids deadly mix NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The autopsy does not make clear if the Halyes knew the cocaine they were taking contained carfentanil — a synthetic opioid 100 times stronger than fentanyl and 1,000 times more powerful than morphine. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR It does indicate, however, that both Halyes took the drug by injection. Courtney Halye had needle puncture marks on her right thigh and left wrist, the report shows, while Brian Halye had a single needle puncture mark on his right arm. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Intentionally injecting cocaine into the body with morphine, heroin or other drugs is known as a “speedball.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The powerful concoction has killed celebrities, including former Saturday Night Live star John Belushi more than three decades ago. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Earlier this month, Hamilton County Coroner Dr. Lakshmi Sammarco warned Cincinnati-area cocaine users that their stashes could be cut with fentanyl or heroin without their knowledge, the Cincinnati Enquirer reported. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Cuyahoga County Medical Examiner Dr. Thomas Gilson last week told a U.S. Senate subcommittee that he believed drug dealers may be mixing cocaine and fentanyl as a way to increase opioid addiction in the black community, according to The (Cleveland) Plain Dealer. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A small amount of carfentanil no larger than a grain of salt can kill. In July, Ohio Attorney General Mike DeWine warned police agencies across the state against handling or field testing street drugs that could contain dangerous levels of fentanyl or carfentanil. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR In September, the Drug Enforcement Administration issued a nationwide warning about the health and safety risks of carfentanil that can also resemble powdered cocaine. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “Just handling it can result in death,” Ken Betz, director of the Montgomery County Coroner’s office, said at the time of the DEA’s warning. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Airline drug tests questioned NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR A Dayton Daily News examination after Halye’s death revealed airline pilots can go years without a drug test. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR The toxicology and autopsy reports do not indicate if Halye had ever used drugs before flying an airplane, but it’s also unknown when Halye was last subjected to a drug test. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR >> MORE: Spirit Airlines pilot may not have been drug tested in years NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “The random nature of testing means that people can in fact get away with things like this,” said Ashley Nunes, a regulatory analyst with the MIT Center for Transportation & Logistics. “It’s certainly concerning to me someone could take cocaine, or have the lack of common sense to take cocaine and fly an airplane.” NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR “I suspect he is not the first and will not be the last,” Nunes said. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Spirit Airlines in March declined to answer the Daily News’ questions about Halye’s last flights, upcoming routes and the dates and results of any drug screenings. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Airlines officials in March said the pilot, who flew for the airline for nine years, captained his last Spirit Airlines flight six days before the overdose.
